title: Cornell still winless after 31-6 loss at Sacred Heart
text:
Cornell still winless after 31-6 loss at Sacred Heart Tom Fleischman, tfleischman@ithacajournal.com | @TomF_IJSports 5:14 p.m. EDT October 18, 2015 With senior Luke Hagy, the Ivy League's leading rusher, sidelined by injury early in the game, Cornell struggled to move the ball and fell to Sacred Heart, 31-6, on Saturday in Fairfield, Conn. Senior Luke Hagy, the Ivy League's leading rusher entering the weekend, was injured on the game's first play Saturday as Cornell lost to Sacred Heart, 31-6. Hagy was kneed in the back of the head and did not return. (Photo: PATRICK SHANAHAN / Provided) Story Highlights Hagy was kneed in the back of the head on the game's first play, and did not return to action Sophomore Josh Sweet gained 80 yards on 22 carries and scored his first career TD for the Red Sacred Heart quarterback R.J. Noel completed 15 of 22 passes for 270 yards and two TDs Cornell starts the second half of the season on Saturday afternoon against visiting Ivy foe Brown CONNECT 4 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
With one of the best running backs in the Ivy League sidelined after being injured on the game's first play, the winless Cornell football team found the going especially tough against defending Northeast Conference champion Sacred Heart. 
The Pioneers limited the Big Red to 280 yards of total offense and used a handful of big plays on both sides of the ball to score a 31-6 Homecoming Weekend triumph on Saturday at Campus Field in Fairfield, Connecticut. 
Sacred Heart, which limited Cornell to 66 rushing yards, improved to 4-2, while Cornell slipped to 0-5. 
Senior Luke Hagy, who led the Ivy League in rushing by one yard over Harvard's Paul Stanton entering the weekend, was kneed in the back of the head by a Sacred Heart defender on his first carry Saturday. He left the game and did not return; his status for Saturday's Ivy League contest against visiting Brown will be determined this week. 
Cornell was already without its second-string running back, freshman Chris Walker, who suffered a concussion in Cornell's 40-3 loss to Harvard a week earlier. Sophomore Josh Sweet saw the most action of his career and gained 80 yards on 22 carries, scoring the Red's lone touchdown early in the second quarter. It was Sweet's first career touchdown. 
Junior quarterback Robert Somborn struggled, completing just 10 of 22 passes for 196 yards with a late interception. Sophomore Jake Jatis was 1-for-3 for 18 yards in limited second-half duty. 
The Pioneers (4-2) were led by quarterback R.J. Noel, who completed 15 of 22 passes for 270 yards and a pair of touchdowns. He hit Moses Webb from 7 yards out late in the first half to put the home team up, 17-6, then capped the scoring in the fourth quarter with an 80-yard bomb to Tyler Dube, who led all receivers with nine catches for 202 yards, seven yards shy of the school record. 
Dube also threw a 1-yard touchdown pass to 300-pound lineman Connor Caveney in the second quarter on a flea-flicker to give the Pioneers a 10-0 lead. 
After forcing eight turnovers a week ago in a 26-13 win over Robert Morris, Sacred Heart was able to keep Cornell's offense off balance all day, posting 11 tackles for losses totaling 64 yards. Cornell also hurt itself with five penalties for 50 yards. 
A turning point in the game came early in the second half, with the Red trailing, 17-6. After forcing a Sacred Heart three-and-out, Cornell marched deep into Pioneers territory and appeared to be on the verge of scoring when Sweet was tackled at the end of a 14-yard run near the goal line. 
The ball popped free and was recovered in the end zone by the home team. Cornell coach David Archer felt Sweet was already down when the ball came loose, but the officials ruled it a fumble and Pioneers ball at the 20 after a touchback. 
Sacred Heart marched 80 yards in 14 plays with the ensuing possession to build a three-score lead. Cornell was able to penetrate Pioneers territory just once after that. 
At the midpoint of the season, Cornell (0-2 Ivies) has just league games the rest of the way, beginning with Saturday's 12:30 p.m. kickoff against the Bears (3-2, 1-1 Ivies), who defeated Princeton on Saturday, 38-31. In other games involving league teams, 24th-ranked Harvard blanked Lafayette, 42-0; Pennsylvania routed Columbia, 42-7; and Yale topped Maine, 21-10. 
Last week, Columbia snapped its 24-game losing streak with a 26-3 defeat of Wagner, leaving the Big Red as the league's lone winless team. Read or Share this story: http://ithacajr.nl/1LE7GRe TOP VIDEOS
